Candlewood Suites Dallas Market Center Love Field, a three-story limited
service hotel conveniently located off of Interstate 35E and easy access to State
Highways 114 & 12 in Dallas, Texas. The hotel consists of 150 guest rooms and
offers amenities including an outdoor pool, sundry shop, lending locker, business
center, 24 hour fitness center, spacious lobby/great room, guest laundry facilities

Dallas will serve as a host city for the 2026 FIFA World Cup, featuring a total of
nine matches. Our Year Two Proforma assumes that the property and market
will benefit from the nine 2026 FIFA World Cup matches in Dallas, Texas. The
Candlewood Suites Dallas Market Center Love Field represents the opportunity
to acquire a franchised hotel in a strong market with several demand drivers.

column1: Candlewood Suites is an affiliate of InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), the world’s first truly international hotel
brand. As of September 2019, IHG has nearly 5,895 hotels comprising of more than 881,562 rooms. In addition, there
are approximately 1,954 hotels in the company’s pipeline comprising of 288,321 rooms. IHG is one of the world’s
leading hotel companies, with 400,000 colleagues working across more than 100 countries to deliver True Hospitality
for everyone. IHG’s goal is to create Great Hotels Guests Love; its brands are in 13 of the 20 largest hotel markets with
more guest rooms than any other hotel company in the world.
The company’s 19 trusted brands range from the friendly comfort of a city-center Holiday Inn Hotel to the luxury of
an award-winning InterContinental resort. IHG’s family of hotel brands has a powerful heritage that guests know and
love, with hotels that are instantly recognized by millions around the world.

column1: Dallas is the third largest city in Texas and the
largest city in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex,
the fourth-largest metropolitan area in the United
States at 7.5 million people. It is the largest city in
and seat of Dallas County with portions extending
into Collin, Denton, Kaufman and Rockwall counties.
With a 2020 census population of 1,304,379, it is the
ninth most-populous city in the U.S. and the third-
largest in Texas after Houston and San Antonio.
Located in the North Texas region, the city of
Dallas is the main core of the largest metropolitan
area in the Southern United States and the largest
inland metropolitan area in the U.S. that lacks any
The cities of Dallas and nearby Fort Worth were
initially developed due to the construction of major
railroad lines through the area allowing access to
cotton, cattle and later oil in North and East Texas.
The construction of the Interstate Highway System
reinforced Dallas's prominence as a transportation
hub, with four major interstate highways converging
in the city and a fifth interstate loop around it.
Dallas then developed as a strong industrial and
financial center and a major inland port, due to
the convergence of major railroad lines, interstate
highways and the construction of Dallas/Fort Worth
International Airport, one of the largest and busiest

column2: Downtown Dallas is the central business district (CBD) of
Dallas, Texas, located in the geographic center of the city. It
is the second-largest business district in the state of Texas.
The area termed "Downtown" has traditionally been defined
as bounded by the downtown freeway loop, bounded on the
east by I-345 (although known and signed as the northern
terminus of I-45 and the southern terminus of US 75 (Central
Expressway), on the west by I-35E, on the south by I-30, and
on the north by Spur 366 (Woodall Rodgers Freeway).
The strong organic growth of Downtown Dallas since
the early 2000s and continuing into the present has now
resulted in Downtown Dallas, Inc.'s expansion of the term
"Downtown" to include the explosive growth occurring
immediately north of the Woodall Rodgers Freeway in the
Victory Park and Uptown/Turtle Creek Districts, as well as
past Central Expressway to the east in the Deep Ellum and
Bryan Place Districts, past Interstate 30 to the south with the
Cedars District, and jumping over Interstate 35E to the west
to include the Design District and Lower Oak Lawn.
Downtown Dallas is now viewed as an interconnected
grouping of dense and urban center city districts, that while
unique in their own right, also share strong urban linkages
to each other and collectively participate in their role as

column1: AT&T STADIUM WILL HOST NINE MATCHES
Dallas is set to be one of the host cities for the 2026 FIFA World
Cup, marking a significant moment in the city’s sports history. As
part of a joint bid by the United States, Canada, and Mexico, Dallas
will play a crucial role in the first World Cup to feature an expanded
48-team format. The matches in Dallas are expected to take place
at the iconic AT&T Stadium, home of the Dallas Cowboys, which
is renowned for its massive seating capacity and cutting-edge
facilities. This venue will offer a world-class experience for both

ability to host large-scale international events.

he event also presents an opportunity for Dallas to further its
legacy in soccer. The city has a strong soccer culture, supported
by Major League Soccer’s FC Dallas and a growing youth soccer
community. By hosting World Cup matches, Dallas aims to inspire
the next generation of soccer players and fans, fostering greater
interest and participation in the sport across the region. This
historic event will undoubtedly leave a lasting impact on Dallas,
cementing its reputation as a premier destination for global sports.
The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, located in Dallas, is a premier academic medical center renowned for its groundbreaking research,
outstanding medical education, and exceptional patient care. Established in 1943, UT Southwestern has grown into a leading institution with more than 2,500
full-time faculty members, including six Nobel laureates. The medical center comprises several hospitals and clinics, offering comprehensive healthcare
services and advanced medical treatments. With a strong emphasis on interdisciplinary collaboration, UT Southwestern fosters innovation in various fields,
including cancer, heart disease, and neurosciences. Its commitment to training the next generation of healthcare professionals is evident through its rigorous
academic programs and state-of-the-art facilities, making it a pivotal institution in advancing medical knowledge and improving health outcomes.

The Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex is the fourth-most populous metro in the nation, with an
aggregate of 7.9 million residents. It is composed of 13 counties, stretching nearly 10,000 square
miles. The core cities of Dallas and Fort Worth house approximately 1.4 million and 990,000
residents, respectively. Strong corporate relocations and the resulting job gains continue to draw
new residents to the region, which has added more than 315,000 more people since the onset
of the COVID-19 health crisis. In keeping with historical trends, Collin and Denton counties have
received the majority of growth. To accommodate the additional roadway traffic, the region’s
transportation network is continually evolving. The expansion of the transportation network is vital
to supporting the substantial developments in housing, retail and industrial, allowing commuters
to access the metro’s numerous corporations and expanding array of industries.
The Metroplex is home to 24 Fortune 500 companies and many
regional headquarters, drawing workers and residents.
Dallas-Fort Worth was the sixth-fastest growing major metro over
the past decade, a trend that is set to continue for the near future.
The area’s extensive network of rail and highways, along with the
International Inland Port of Dallas and multiple airports, solidify its
status as a national distribution hub.
